Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Machine Vision Enhanced Post Earthquake Inspection and Rapid Loss Estimation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to develop and validate a computational framework for post-earthquake inspection of reinforced concrete (RC) frame buildings that will enable rapid, automated assessment of the damage state of the structure and of the cost and time required to repair the structure. The proposed automated procedure will start with collection of video frames using a high-resolution video camera mounted on an inspector?s hardhat. Then, state-of-the-art detection and extraction algorithms will be employed to detect RC columns and identify and characterize column damage. Component damage will be classified using empirically based models, and component damage will be used to determine the damage state of the building. Building damage state, configuration and type will be used to query a set of fragility curves defining the likelihood of building collapse during an aftershock and, thereby, provide an improved understanding of risk. Deliverables include a catalog of fundamental visible damage characteristics, model-based recognition and analysis tools, demonstration and validation via hardware, documentation of research results, engineering student education, and outreach seminars to building evaluators.

If successful, the results of this research will provide the first robust method in the area of structural member and damage recognition from video. This scientific breakthrough will allow researchers to integrate this work in as-built building information modeling, project monitoring, virtual and augmented reality and other applications of importance to the engineering community. Also, this will be the first known study to quantitatively link visual damage in a building component (column or wall), to the likelihood of building collapse using robust probabilistic methods. The discoveries sought in this project are expected to serve as a foundation for a new knowledge base in damage assessment and to promote intellectual cross-pollination among the fields of computer vision and structural engineering. The results will be disseminated to allow the creation of commercial software that have increased precision, reduced cost, and work with reduced weight devices. Graduate and undergraduate engineering students and K-12 students will benefit through classroom instruction and involvement in the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research consists of three sub-activities such as the detection of visible damage, identification of experimental-based column response mechanism, and development of aftershock fragilities for damaged buildings. Each sub-activity was inter-correlated with one another to construct a complete framework for rapid post-earthquake inspection and loss estimation method. Key outcomes have been addressed:

1. Visible damage detection

1) Concrete Column Detection: A new concrete column detection method was created, which considers the column’s material and shape information as detection cues. The method can locate concrete column surfaces in images. The effectiveness of the method was verified through a series of tests on real concrete column images.

2) Crack Detection and Property Retrieval: State-of-the-art crack detection methods were compared, and a percolation-based method was selected and adapted to produce a crack map on each concrete column surface. A new algorithm consisting of image thinning, distance transform, and skeleton split-and-merge was invented to retrieve the width, length and orientation of the cracks in the map. The algorithm was tested on a series of crack maps on damaged RC column images.

3) Exposed Reinforcement Detection: A new algorithm was invented that considers damaged regions of concrete column surfaces and automatically detects any exposed reinforcement in the region. The image was initially thresholded using a double-adaptive threshold, and this was followed by the application of a template matching algorithm. The image was post-processed to account for the typical size and shape of reinforcement with respect to RC columns. This algorithm implemented into a C# based prototype and tested on a series of damaged RC column images.

4) Spalling Detection and Property Retrieval: A new machine vision algorithm was created which identifies spalled regions of concrete column surfaces and extracts key properties of the spalled region. The exposed reinforcement detection algorithm developed in the previous year was integrated into this algorithm such that the exposure of longitudinal reinforcement was identified as a property of the depth of the spalled region. The algorithm was tested on a series of damaged real concrete column images.

5) Damage Index: A new algorithm was created which automatically determines the damage state index of reinforced concrete columns in post-earthquake scenarios. The crack detection and property retrieval and spalling detection and property retrieval methods were utilized such that the column damage considered in the damage state index could be automatically retrieved. For a given image, the visible damage was detected, the properties of that damage were retrieved, and then, a search algorithm was initiated to determine which of several damage state indices the column belonged in. The algorithm was tested on a dataset of real concrete column images varying with respect to the amount of damage.

2. Definition of damage states

The column tests performed by Sezen (2002) (shear-critical) and Bae (2005) (flexure-critical) were studied, in addition to damaged column images from the NEES database and Haiti earthquake etc. Damage states for both shear- and flexure-critical columns were defined, based on the visual damage cues to be detected using machine vision algorithms.

3. Analytical aftershock fragility assessment

1) Numerical component models: Analytical model of critical components in buildings that can dominate global collapse are updated.
